Article: You begin to realize the reality of a technology when it hits mainstream national radio. While mass-produced thinking robots might still be a few years away, in the engineering world, weâre already used to automation of many tasks, and the advance of Industrie 4.0 or the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) is a good example of this. As if to take this to the next step, a Lisbon, Portugal-based startup, MOV.AI, announced seed funding of $3 million to develop what it says is an âindustry-grade operating systemâ for autonomous intelligent collaborative robots that will help deliver what TechCrunch calls an âAndroid for robotics.â The funding was led by Herzeliya, Israel-based Viola Ventures and San Francisco, -based NFX. Viola has investments in companies like Multiphy, which develops DSP and mixed-signal ASICs for data center infrastructure connectivity; Protean, which monitors IC biometrics from production and through its lifecycle; and ColorChip, which develops hyperscale optical transceivers. MOV.AI said that it is creating an ecosystem where developers, integrators, and manufacturers collaborate to produce smarter robots on a large scale for operation and production lines. Its OS is supposed to decouple hardware from software to simplify R&D and field implementation processes. It allows for adding sensors and actuators easily and integrating them for complex behavior, with the ability for field technicians to configure complex behaviors and multi-robot states. This should enable integration with robotic arms, safety programmable logic controllers, charging systems, backoffice enterprise software, and warehouse management software.
